_prev_prog_3.Description:
The process chemistry of the Boron Triflouride (BF3) make up system involves BF3 and hexanol being molecularly completed and stored in F4-122. F458 and F445 are used as serving tanks that charge reactors. After reacting with other compounds in the reactor, BF3 is neutralized with caustic upon entering the reactor.



The processes at the Plant have hazards that are managed to ensure continued safe operation. Plant has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and, (3) reduce (mitigate) the consequences of a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

1. Release detection - sensors with audible alarms, video surveillance, operator rounds

2. Release containment/controls - pressure relief valves, excess flow check valves, dikes, deluge

3. Release mitigation - SOP, training, PPE

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The Firestone Polymers, LLC (Firestone) Lake Charles, Louisiana Plant (the "facility") is a synthetic rubber manufacturing facility.  Firestone is subject to regulation under 40 CFR 68, Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (CAPP).  At the facility, Firestone has the following substances at quantities that are regulated substances for Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) under Subpart F of CAPP: 1,3-Butadiene, 2-Butene cis, 2-Butene-trans, and Boron Trifluoride.



Facilities holding more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process are required to comply with EPA's Risk Management Program regulations. The regulations require owners or operators of covered facilities to implement a risk management program and to submit an RMP to the EPA.



The Lake Charles Plant includes a Program 3 process that is regulated under the ARP Program.

- The facility stores both flammable and toxic substances above threshold quantities which are defined in Tables 1through 4 of 40 CFR 68.130,

- A worst-case release of the flammable substance would affect public receptors,

- A worst-case release of the toxic substance would affect public receptors; and 

- It is a staffed facility that is subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



It is Firestone's policy to meet or exceed all safety, health, and environmental regulations and industrial standards that apply to our facility. Over the years, Firestone has invested significant resources into compliance with the OSHA Process Safety Management and related OSHA standards and have expanded its programs to meet the requirements of the EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) Rule. These programs help maintain low levels of risks to our employees, contractors, the community, and the environment.  This is achieved through: (1) min

imizing the possibility of serious plant upsets through engineering and procedural safeguards and (2) thoroughly planning contingencies in coordination with local responding agencies.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



Our commitment of resources to our RMP program is ongoing, and we take pride in their success. Each program is intended to be used in combination with each other to help prevent unwanted deviations from normal daily operations and to manage any process abnormalities in a way that minimizes the potential for harm within our fence line and beyond. Firestone does not consider safety to be a stand-alone practice but, rather, a fundamental element of all aspects of our daily operations. 



The facility has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68 and maintains a risk management program consisting of the following:

A. Management Systems

B. Hazard Assessment

C. Accident Prevention Program

D. Emergency Response Program

E. Risk Management Plan Submittals



The facility has implemented the following programs elements that are important to ongoing prevention program: Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Employee Participation, Contractor Management, Hot Work, Incident Investigation, and Compliance Audits.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no incidents at the Firestone Polymers, Lake Charles facility that would qualify for inclusion in the RMP 5-year accident history.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Firestone Polymers has a written emergency response plan that is coordinated with the Calcasieu Parish LEPC, the Carlyss Fire Department, Southwest Louisiana Mutual Aid Association, and other local responders. The facility trains all new personnel on the plan, conducts refresher training annually, and

keeps its personnel aware of any changes to the plan. Our emergency response plan complies with the RMP Rule and other applicable EPA requirements.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Firestone regularly reviews our safety program and institute revisions as appropriate to enhance safety and promote continuous improvement of our operations.
